addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my singular good Lord
e L Burghley, Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England

10 June
1589
From M
r
Bodley to the Lord T
hre
r

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
L. I have heerew
t
sent
a copie
of
e
Generall states
answear, to that w
ch
I p
roposed
in my
L. Willughbies
behalf. I am half
of opinion
that they will put me of w
t
shiftes and de
lays and
perfourme nothing in
e end, of that whic
h is re-
quired. I doe not dout but yo
r
L. is ad-
vertised from
Flushing,
of
e apprehending
of
Adrian
Vasseur
S
r
William Russels
Secretary: and w
hat has
passed uppon it, between
e Garrisons and
Middlebourgh.
The matter hath bin fully
debated
heere in a full assembly of
e Generall s
tates and
e Councell of state together: wherein it h
ath bin re-
solved, that seing he was taken out of
e
liberties
Flushing, and is a naturall borne subject
of this con-
trey, he ought to be proceeded against heer
never-
theles to avoid all suspic
o
n of partialitie
it was
agreed, that he should be removed from
e
states
of Zeland
to
e
Councell of state
: and shou
ld be
alwaies examined in my presence, or in
e p
resence
of some other minister of her
Ma
tie
.
wheruppon
they
req
e
sted me to write to
e Lieutenant Gover
no
r
of
Flushing,
at
ei Captaines there would surce
ase from
using any Violence, or threatning
e inhabita
nts of
Middlebourgh. For mine owne part, I can n
ot perceive
that any clause of e Contract, doth favo
r
the Garri-
son in their clame, for deciding
e cause.
In w[ch
respect, as likewise for that I sawe a gre
at discon-
tentm
t
towardes, if they should be resis
ted in this
place, in a mater of justice: and because I
cannot
conceave, howe
e Captaines can stand uppon
their
challeng in equitie, I have joined w
t
e sta
te
and written to
M
r
Borlas
and
M
r
Erring
ton
that
they would accept of suche order, as
e states s
et
downe. I can not omitte to acq
uaint yo
r
L. w
t
a necessary point of this Consultation
offered
in a speeche delivered by
Barnevelt,
in
e
behalf of the
Generall states, wherein
e Councell of state was requi-]
red to write a letter unto her Ma[tie precisely
signifi-
eng, that unles her Hig
nes
would take order f
or the
governing of her people in these contreis, they
would be
be forced to publishe to
e world the whole course
of
fol.44v
o
r
actions from
e beginning, so as all men shall
see in what sort we have proceeded in this contrey:
whiche for speciall respectes they have hitherto thought
good, to keepe secret. This kind of speeche was
utterly condemned by
e Councell of state, who thought
it sufficient to write to
e
LL.
of her Ma
ties
councell,
and to write w
t
more good maner, and regard of
their duty, as will appeere by their letter already
sent. Of suche indignities offered, if I would signi-
fie as often, as occasions are ministred, I should
comber yo
r
L. w
t
many unpleasant letters and ad-
vertisments. And besides if her Ma
tie
would seeme
to take notice of them, and require
e reparation of
her Hono
r
, I see that
e humo
r
heere of some would
waxe more perverse and obstinat uppon it, and not
yeld in
e end to any honorable satisfaction.
In my Voiage homeward from
Berghen,
I came by
Dordrecht,
where I dealt w
t
e Magistrates about
e
release of
S
r
John Wingfildes
childe:
wherein I
found many difficulties, especially for
at S
r
John
had passed a graunt under his hand (whiche
they shewed me) that they should have the custo-
die of his child, till
e debt were answeared,
besides other allegations, wherew
t
it is needeles to
troble yo
r
L. But in
e end I obtened so muche,
that two daies after my departure,
e child was
sett at libertie by publicke sentence. The
Ennemie is thought to bende his forces towardes
B lien-
beecke
and
Hoesden,
albeit stoare of raine, w
ch
hath
bin heere of late, hath caused him to retire from Hoesden.
The towne hath had a newe supplie of men and victu-
als, so as it is furnished w
t
a 1000 souldiers at
e lest, and w
t
victuals for all this Sommer. Some
outrages have bin co
m
itted among those w
t
in
e towne
amo
whiche I thinke are appeared. Muche cattel
hath bin caried away by
e Ennemie, out of
Bo
m
els
weert
, and a 100 men, w
ch
were sent by
Coronell
Balfoure
out of Bommell, to skirmishe w
t
them, were
slaine. At Blienbeecke there is nothing
yet done by
S
r
Martin Schincke
, for
at
e
Count of
Neuwenar
, and
e
Count of Overstein
, by whose forces
fol.45r
he was to be assisted, have hitherto detracte
d the time
and lost great opportunities: and all upp
on private
displeasure, and a litle emulation. The
re are cer-
taine gentlemen of
Frise,
at have raised
of late up-
pon their owne charge, 1600 footmen, for so
me secret
exploit, under
e conduct of one
Clandt,
who hath
promised
e states to joine himself first w
t
Sir Martin
Schincke, for
e succor of Blienbeecke, where
the number
of o
r
men already are 2000 foote, and 70
0 horse
But
e Ennemie is farre stronger, and not
to be
beaten, but by some strategeme, whiche S
chincke
hath undertaken. It is told me
for certain
by Count Maurice,
at
Parma
sendeth out
of
Artois
3000 footemen, and 800 horse, to
e ai
d of the
Liguers.
Thus I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. 10 June 89
Yo
r
L most humbly bounden Tho. Bodl
ey
It is certified by letters from
Collen,
at Parma hath failed of
an enterprise, that he intended
uppon
Metz,
wherein he imploied
800 Italians, uppon secret intelli-
gence w
t
some w
t
in
e towne, who
are also apprehended, and executed.
